huge pain to actually set up maintain manage your own file storage so to
address this you know whole set of pain points around setting up and managing
provisioning storage based on your capacity expectations and then needing to reprovision based on storage changes
and things like that we actually launched Amazon EFS about a year and a half back and what amazon EFS is is a
fully managed file service that provides you a way to create file systems in a
very simple way in a matter of minutes and then to basically not have to worry about any of the file serving
infrastructure itself all of the file serving infrastructure is fully managed by the service everything from setup and
management to actually taking care of the capacity itself your capacit
actually grows elastically so you don't need to worry about provisioning a
certain amount of storage capacity upfront all you do is you know start using your applications and add data
modify data delete data as the applications proceed and the storage
itself elastically grows and shrinks as your usage changes and Amazon EFS is
also built to be scalable in the sense that as your storage scales up your
performance also scales up so you don't need to worry about you know will I get the appropriate performance depending on
the amount of storage capacity I have and it's also scalable in the sense that it's shareable across not just a few
clients but across up to thousands of client instances of easy to instances and another aspect of the simplicity of
EFS itself is it exports the file storage as an NFS accessible file system
so you can actually use the standard NFS protocol you can basically use any Linux
ec2 instance that has NFS clients installed which is default in all modern
Linux distributions and you get to use your filesystem in a very simple way and
then of course Amazon EFS is built to be highly available in durable and data
itself is redundant lis stored across multiple availability zones and you don't need to worry about making sure
that you are protected against you know component failures fail overs and things
like that so in essence it provides you a very simple elastic and scalable file
system that you just create in a matter of minutes and use from your applications and not have to worry about
any of the management complexities EFS
is designed for a wide spectrum of application needs so it really targets
the workloads across an entire spectrum starting from you know low latency and
serial i/o intensive applications on one side things like developer to laying
home directories container storage all the way up on the other end to scale our jobs that require very high
levels of throughput and parallel i/o ups and so on you know what codes like big data
analytics media and entertainment workflows and so on and then in the middle there's all kinds of applications
everything from web serving and content management to enterprise workloads and database backups and messaging and so on
so it really is targeted at a very wide variety of applications no matter what
the specific performance needs are and these are some examples of EFS customers
across this entire variety of use case scenarios that are using EFS today so in
terms of the security model itself EFS actually provides multiple layers of security so you can actually control the
network traffic that goes back and forth between your ec2 instances that are
mounting the file system itself and and the actual file system using VPC
security groups and network ackles you can actually control individual file and directory level access using POSIX
permissions which is what file workloads in general are used to from decades as
Paul mentioned and then you can control administrative access to your file system the API access to your file
system using AWS I am and you can do both resource level and action level permissions and then
you can also recently we launched support for encryption of data at rest so you can actually use keys managed in

simple you don't need to worry about actually encrypting and decrypting the data you just set it all up and the
service itself takes care of all of the encryption in the backend so let's talk
about how you can actually use Amazon EFS and how it looks to your clients so the EFS file system itself is a you
know hierarchical directory structure as you would use any file system and then that is presented as a set of
mount targets which are basically end points in each of your availability zones within a given V PC that you have
configured and then there's a common DNS name that appropriately maps to a mount
argot depending on which AZ you're using the dns name from and all you need to do is from your NFS clients from your ec2
instances themselves you just issue a simple mount command as you would any NFS file system and you know you you
point the mount command at that dns name and once the file system itself is mounted your applications get to use the
files and directories as if they're using any other files and directories so
as I mentioned it's designed for a wide variety of applications and workloads the way it enables you to use the same
service across a wide range of workloads is basically by providing two
performance modes we provide general-purpose performance more than the max i/o performance mode the general
purpose performance mode is the default one and that's really what we recommend for the vast majority of applications
out there applications that are latency sensitive and just general purpose in nature and then the advantage there is
you actually get the lowest latencies for individual file operations but then the trade-off there is there's a limit
of up to 7,000 operations per second that you can perform per file system and
this really is the best choice for most workloads because we have found that most customers find this to be the happy
spot and then we also provide another performance mode called the max I hope formance mode in which you can actually
achieve larger scale of throughput and I ops and you use this generally for large
scale analytics applications data heavy applications and so on and here you actually get virtually unlimited ability
to scale out throughput RI ops there's no you know specified limit as in the other case with the trade-off of
slightly higher per operational agencies which usually does not matter for you
know massively parallel applications that tend to use this performance mode in
terms of the data storage itself EFS actually distributes the data across an
unconstrained number of servers across multiple availability zones and this design really helps avoid the
bottlenecks that are a result of traditional file server designs and it
enables very high levels of aggregate I ups and throughput because of this design of unconstrained number of
servers and then the distribution of the data across multiple availability zones is also what enables the high
availability and durability that EFS is able to offer so an implication of this
highly distributed data storage design is that the per operation latency
